fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A cartesian closed category is a cartesian monoidal category whose monoidal structure is closed. In this case, we call the internal hom [x, y] an exponential object, and write it y^x.

Categories for the Working Mathematician provides an array of general ideas useful in a wide variety of fields. Starting from the foundations, this book illuminates the concepts of category, functor, natural transformation, and duality. The book then turns to adjoint functors, which provide a description of universal constructions, an analysis of the representations of functors by sets of morphisms, and a means of manipulating direct and inverse limits. These categorical concepts are extensively illustrated in the remaining chapters, which include many applications of the basic existence theorem for adjoint functors. The categories of algebraic systems are constructed from certain adjoint-like data and characterized by Beck's theorem. After considering a variety of applications, the book continues with the construction and exploitation of Kan extensions. This second edition includes a number of revisions and additions, including two new chapters on topics of active interest. One is onsymmetric monoidal categories and braided monoidal categories and the coherence theorems for them. The second describes 2-categories and the higher dimensional categories which have recently come into prominence. The bibliography has also been expanded to cover some of the many other recent advances concerning categories.
Set is cartesian closed.
An elementary topos is a category which:
This is not a minimal definition; many of these pieces of structure imply each other.

It remains to show the desired adjunction. Since 1_y is terminal in C/y, a map n\to \Pi _f m in C/y induces, again by the universal property of the pullback, a unique map n\to \left [c\xrightarrow {m} x\xrightarrow {f} y^{(x\xrightarrow {f} y)}\right ] whose post-composition with m is the identity 1_f. Taking the transpose yields a map \left [f\times n\right ]\xrightarrow {g^\dag } \left [c\xrightarrow {m}x\xrightarrow {f} y\right ]. However, the product in C/y is exactly the pullback in C, so that (since mg = 1_x), this is equivalently a map f^*n\to m in C/x.
A cartesian closed category is bicartesian closed if it additionally has finite coproducts; equivalently, it is a bicartesian category whose cartesian monoidal structure is closed.

fr:title.text: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian category, a cartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

To see the first, note that C(-, 1^x)\cong C(-\times x, 1)\cong *, and the Yoneda embedding reflects limits, so that 1^x is terminal in C. for a more abstract proof, observe that (-)^x has a right adjoint, so preserves limits.
To see the second, note that C(-, x^1)\cong C(-\times 1, x)\cong C(-, x), and representable isomorphism is isomorphism.

To see the third, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, (y\times z)^x) &\cong C(-\times x, y\times z) \\ &\cong C(-\times x, y)\times C(-\times x, z) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x)\times C(-, z^x) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x\times z^x). \end {aligned} In particular, the second step uses the representability of limits.

To see the fourth, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y\times z}) &\cong C(-, x^{z\times y}) \\ &\cong C(-\times (z\times y), x) \\ &\cong C((-\times z)\times y, x) \\ &\cong C(-\times z, x^y) \\ &\cong C(-, (x^y)^z). \end {aligned}

A global element of an object X in a cartesian closed category (or sometimes more generally a closed monoidal category, in which case the same concept is sometimes called a generalized element or state) is a morphism 1\to X.
For any category C, the category of presheaves \hat {C} is cartesian closed.

Products are computed pointwise, hence inherited from Set. By the Yoneda lemma, for c\in C an exponential Q^P, if it exists, should satisfy Q^P c \cong \hat {C}(yc, Q^P)\cong \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). Taking this to define Q^P, we now show the desired adjunction.

Fixing some P and Q suffices to construct the evaluation natural transformation Q^P\times P\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} Q (itself the Q-component of a natural transformation (-)^P\times P\to P) which induces an isomorphism on adjoint hom-sets. At c\in C, the component \operatorname {ev}_c is given a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\phi } Q and an element p\in Pc; we define \operatorname {ev}_c(\phi , p) = \phi _c(1_c, p).

Now, it remains to show that there is a bijection \hat {C}(R, Q^P)\xrightarrow {-\times P} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q^P\times P)\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}_*} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q). That is, given a natural transformation R\times P\xrightarrow {\alpha } Q, we must show that there is a unique natural transformation R\xrightarrow {\beta } Q^P mapping to \alpha . At c\in C, this is a set-function Rc\xrightarrow {\beta _c} Q^Pc, where the latter is the set \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). As such, for each element r\in Rc, we must define a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\beta _c(r)} Q.

A closed monoidal category is a symmetric monoidal category C such that the bifunctor \otimes is closed. Explicitly, this means there is a bifunctor C^\text {op}\times C\xrightarrow {[-, -]} C, called the internal hom, together with a natural isormorphism C(x\otimes y, z)\cong C(x, [y, z]), called currying.
The counit of the adjunction (-\otimes y)\dashv [y, -] is called evaluation: it is a natural transformation [y, x]\otimes y\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} x.

Applying the adjunction with x the monoidal unit I implies that maps y\to z are in natural bijection with maps I\to [y, z]. By the philosophy of generalized elements, this explains the name internal hom: its elements are maps.

A monoidal category is cartesian if its monoidal product is the cartesian product (and so its monoidal unit is terminal); any category with finite products is monoidal in this way. Dually, it is cocartesian if it has finite coproducts, and bicartesian if it has both.
